channel.title: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores
channel.description:
So this is a question I ask myself most of the time. Especially when I see others uploading their tracks to places like iTunes or spotify. I always wonder whether I should or I shouldn’t. My IRL friends think I should and it is tempting to do so.
I will never upload any Auxy track to Stores, following this: In the future when I am able to afford a real DAW (I hope sooner than later) I will remove every Auxy track I have made from SoundCloud. Either this or creating a New Soundcloud to upload Music on.
The reason for this that Auxy really doesn’t cut it for me, Don’t get me wrong Auxy is the best mobile Music app out there and is great for getting down ideas on the go. I have spent the past 2 to 3 years learning the ins and outs of Sound design and music theory, only to find I can’t do anything yet.
I don’t want to release something into stores that doesnt refelct my personality. I haven’t yet shown my true self through music because I am limited: I have ideas I cant write down, I have full compositions I cannot express fully.
And Just having this in my head I know isn’t healthy. Which Is why on my first and last Album release (Auxy made) I will leave Auxy and its community most likely for good.
Im sorry if I disappoint those who are expecting me to continue using Auxy for ever. I won’t.
Maybe you can change your mind and tell me what you think of my idea, Is it stupid? The next Distress message will be on the 23rd where I will preview the Album for everyone.
EDIT: Collaborations do not apply to this as I believe it depends on the other person(s)
~X

item.title: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
Mmmm yeah I don’t think there is any cross talk between hardware and link. That would be pretty wild!

Edit: I bet if you look hard enough though there is some Raspberry Pi based hardware to software converter lol… there’s so many weird Raspberry Pi things out there haha

item.title: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
I’m pretty sure with link there is no concept of master and slave, they act as peers with tempo information. Changing one changes them all, this may or may not be what you want though.

In the current version they don’t share play start/stop information but I think that’s coming next version.

Read full topic

I want Auxy as a slave.

Did you ever check these out? Do they do what you need?
(What’s wrong with Ableton Link being part of the solution?)

Post your great Auxy feature idea here! Auxy Feedback
That’s part of it.

Read full topic
item.source: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores

item.title: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores
item.dc:creator: Offcmd
item.description:
Let me chime in with another perspective.
I think limitations are a bless.
I used to produce all my music in Ableton, however I felt that with endless tools and VSTs I often got lost and instead of learning I got caught in the details of finding the right sound, tweaking notes endlessly and such.

The real joy came to me when I started using physical instruments, like drum machines, sampler, fx, a mixer, etc.

Auxy has allowed me to quickly sketch melodies on the go. ( Most of my Auxy tracks are done during commute on the subway and yes, I constantly miss my station )
I then may sample phrases or even single shots from Auxy and incorporate them into my live set. Other times I simply re-create a melody I made in Auxy on the sampler or keyboard.

Having a limited palette and hardware memory has allowed me to focus on composition and live performance and I’ve learned a lot more than years on a DAW.

I now even use Auxy on an iPad along physical instruments and trigger loops manually, often adjusting tempo of drum machine on the fly to match tempo, a skill that is lost with DAW’s

I am still looking forward to a feature that would allow Auxy to sync to a midi clock as a slave and without any computer involved (no ableton link please).

In the meantime, I can only get better at tempo syncing manually and become more dexterous.

Nothing wrong with using Auxy as a professional instrument or even the only source of your music, as long as is good stuff and you learn in the process!

Read full topic

item.source: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores

item.title: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Software companies will typically provide some mechanism to retrieve your lost access code.
The software itself can typically be downloaded again from the company website.

i.e. there’s rarely, if ever, any need to torrent software you legitimately own - especially when all you need is your access/registration code.

(FYI, having a license to use the software doesn’t make it ‘more legal’ to download pirated/kracked copies of the software.)

Read full topic

item.title: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores
item.dc:creator: TheRealJFalc
item.description:
foryou:

torrent

Some people don’t like to torrent things.

Xiejra:

I have used FL studio demo in the past (Made sound design using image lines Harmor, up on my SC) I have a mac anyway and I would rather use Ableton instead.

I only recommended FL studio since it’s what I use for mastering now and composing outside of auxy xD but yeah I understand the whole limiting thing. If you need presets for things like Serum I’ve been designing plenty, shoot me a message and I’ll send over a couple nice ones.

item.source: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores

item.title: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores
item.dc:creator: blakkaz
item.description:
I remember watching an interview (from memory in might have been with Richie Hawtin) discussing the difference between having your music dictated by the software versus finding something that lets you truly express yourself.

Given Auxy’s limited feature set and only ~100 synth presets, I’ve never felt like I could capture ‘my sound’ without extra tools.

Read full topic
item.source: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores

item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
Yeah I was gonna say, if you’ve been sinking your teeth into something like Harmor you’re gonna be hard pressed to find an equivalent, especially in a mobile app…

I fully agree with what @BALLISTIK says - I switch back and forth between different apps and programs all the time. It’s part of the process. Right now, I’m getting 90% of what I need out of solely Auxy. If/when that changes later we’ll see how things go

item.source: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores

item.title: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores
item.dc:creator: BALLISTIK
item.description:
I know how you feel, I’ve been using Logic Pro for close to 3 years and I’m still learning how to do it. However, if you take the time to use a complex DAW like Logic or Ableton a lot, you will start to become more and more productive.
To elaborate, I tend to go back and forth between both programs (Auxy and Logic Pro.) I get tired of Logic Pro, and then use Auxy. Eventually, I get sick of Auxy and come back to Logic Pro again. Both programs do different things for me. Auxy has allowed me to grow in my knowledge of songwriting/producing. Logic Pro is much more versatile, and thus lets me be more flexible.
In the end, I think Logic Pro X is probably going to be my go-to DAW. But, in the words of Andrew Huang: “the studio is a kind of living, breathing animal. It’s constantly changing to fit whatever I’m doing.” I have certainly found this to be true, so I use both.

Just my really long and elaborate personal opinion

Read full topic
item.source: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores

item.source: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores

item.title: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores
item.dc:creator: TheRealJFalc
item.description:
I’d recommend exporting the projects to a mastering app such as FL studio to master your tracks, and even export the midi out and using other instruments instead of others to achieve different sounds not capable with Auxy as of now. Auxy’s mixing is ok, but it’s not perfect. Pro tip when sending over, remove effects such as Delay, Reverb and make the volume not maxed on parts to avoid clipping.

Read full topic

item.source: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores

item.title: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
I understand completely where you’re coming from with this.

The phrase I use is ‘Auxy finished’, as I’m yet to produce something that I feel would sit well next to - and, yes, compete with - music made using more traditional, professional processes.

Consequently, all my pieces that I think have potential for proper commercial release are named/tagged as ‘demos’.

Now, I may be overly critical, but I can’t shake that nagging voice that each of those tracks can and should be ‘finished properly’ before properly pushing them out into the world.

I think there is enough potential in each track to ‘be something’ that I’m reluctant to release them without that polish. I feel like it could waste the good potential that those pieces might have.

It’s not about the track being ‘perfect’, but about sufficiently closing the gap between what I’ve made in Auxy and what’s out there to give my tracks a reasonable, fighting chance.

Now, all that said, I am actually planning to work with a composer/producer friend to actually make that happen, and to finish (no air quotes) those tracks in the next couple of months.

If I didn’t have solid plans set to make that happen, I would definitely be pushing my stuff up onto Spotify, etc… already. Until they’re out there in the world, they have zero chance of getting traction and doing me any good - which means that all the time and effort I put into them really is wasted.

Read full topic
item.source: Why I will never upload my Auxy tracks to stores
